attraction_reviewComments: The park makes for a great walk along the harbor. You can get very close to the yachts and other boats. There are plenty of benches for resting or people watching. The... read more
this is the perfect place on a beautiful san diego afternoon to just walk and look at people!
We had such a great time strolling slowly on the Harbourside. The little shops are very cute and idyllic, nice place for lunch.
We love coming here, because there is great food, a wonderful breeze, and amazing views. You get to see the ships, go to a naval ship museum, eat, or shop. There is always that... read more
Lots to see walking around the Embarcadero. Anthony's Fish Grotto is there, Star of India ship and other antique ships there, sculptures, people watching and great water views.
In 2014 there was lots of construction taking place along the Embarcadero. This year we got to enjoy all of the work and it's fantastic! Lots more places to sit and relax. More... read more
The Embarcadero has something different going on every time we visit. It is always nice to see the USS Midway and the Star of India, but there are various cruise ships that dock... read more
We walked the length of the whole Embarcadero area starting from where the Cruise Boats depart to the end of the Convention Center. Beautiful to see all the boats in the Marina.
Describing this area would be different depending on what you want to do. For us, a nice walk looking at the museum boats, the waterfront, the airplanes and the changing night sky... read more

enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.

This was a Christmas present for my husband, so it wasn't my idea. I was pleasantly surprised and had a good time. Theatre is small, but it was perfect for this event.
A wonderful place - historic, with a unique atmosphere, harkening back to a glamorous past yet modernized for a wonderful cinema experience. If there's a movie I'm at all... read more
The Arlington is a wonderful old theater with character and charm. You may just forget what you came to see and find yourself gazing at the... well go and see!
it is very old and historic the inside is beautifully painted with small balconies that are fake but, a nice touch. the ceiling is painted black with twinkling small stars. it... read more
There isn't another theater in the country (to my knowledge) with a gorgeous Spanish Colonial tiled entry foyer complete with fountains. Just seeing that transports you to the... read more
Worth a visit to see an event. As the lights dim, the stars come out on the ceiling. Beautiful theater.
Went to the Arlington Theater to see Magic Johnson's inspirational speech. Beautiful, nostalgic theater with a Mexican Village theme along the side walls. Could have used some... read more
Awesome place to see a movie in an large, elegant, old style movie theatre. Stars twinkle in the ceiling, interior looks like an old spanish village. Lovely large theatre with a... read more

enrich_metadata.abstract: Escondido (/ˌɛskənˈdiːdoʊ/ ES-kən-DEE-doh) is a city located in San Diego County's North County region, 30 miles (48 km) northeast of Downtown San Diego, California. The city occupies a shallow valley ringed by rocky hills. Incorporated in 1888, it is one of the oldest cities in San Diego County. The city had a population of 143,911 at the 2010 census. Its municipal government set itself an operating budget limit of $426,289,048 for the fiscal year 2010–2011. The city is known as Eskondiid in Diegueño.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Escondido,_California

The city occupies a shallow valley ringed by rocky hills. Incorporated in 1888, it is one of the oldest cities in San Diego County. The city had a population of 143,911 at the 2010 census. Its municipal government set itself an operating budget limit of $426,289,048 for the fiscal year 2010–2011. The city is known as Eskondiid in Diegueño.

A portion of the beach was closed because it was mating season for the seals, but that was expected. There were lots of places to eat, the beach was clean, and the sun was warm... read more
We had a blast here. We went many times during our week in San Diego. Don not miss the experience. Getting to see seals close up and sit with them is sooooooo cool. Then you can... read more
Having fun selfie with the seals and getting nice shots with the sea and the birds. So wonderful to walk there. A bit of bad smell but you will get used with it soon.
This beach has some of the most beautiful views of San Diego. The Sea Lions are very entertaining as well the clear blue waters! Make sure you give them a visit, and go through... read more
Just park and walk! The beauty will amaze you! So much wild life between the birds and the seals. Lots of folks snorkeling! Very peaceful and interesting!
The sound of waves and the sea lions all basking on the shores , the gorgeous sun and cool fresh air is a winning combination. We went there to see the sunset and had dinner as... read more
Amazing spot, where you can really get in close encounter with seals and birds of the sea, nice beach as well but couldn't go swimming because of the time. The cave itself is not... read more
Visiting La Jolla Cove was my favorite part of our trip to San Diego. The views are absolutely stunning all around. I felt like a big kid when we went to sea lion beach! You can... read more
this is a great activity while visit SD I visited with my family and kids and they were very happy walking and sightseeing the area
Childrens beach is closed for breeding season until the end of May so we couldn't walk down to the beach. We did have fun watching the seals. However the next cove down you... read more
When I lived in San Diego, I've only visited here once. Once I moved to other city 2 hours away, this is one of the handful of places I can't wait to visit when I go to San Diego... read more

enrich_metadata.mention_address: Palmdale, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Palmdale is a city in the center of northern Los Angeles County in the U.S. state of California. The San Gabriel Mountains separate Palmdale from the City of Los Angeles. On August 24, 1962, Palmdale became the first community in the Antelope Valley to incorporate. 47 years later, in November 2009, voters approved making it a charter city. Its population was 152,750 at the 2010 census, up from 116,670 at the 2000 census. Palmdale is the 33rd most populous city in California. In 2013, the Palmdale / Lancaster urban area had an estimated population of 513,547.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Palmdale,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Palmdale is a city in the center of northern Los Angeles County in the U.S. state of California. The San Gabriel Mountains separate Palmdale from the City of Los Angeles.On August 24, 1962, Palmdale became the first community in the Antelope Valley to incorporate. 47 years later, in November 2009, voters approved making it a charter city. Its population was 152,750 at the 2010 census, up from 116,670 at the 2000 census. Palmdale is the 33rd most populous city in California. In 2013, the Palmdale / Lancaster urban area had an estimated population of 513,547.

enrich_metadata.label: Inglewood, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Inglewood is a city in southwestern Los Angeles County, California, southwest of downtown Los Angeles. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the city had a population of 109,673. It was incorporated on February 14, 1908. The city is in the South Bay region of the Greater Los Angeles Area. City of Champions Stadium is under construction in the city and when finished around 2019 will be the home of the Los Angeles Rams, which moved back to the Los Angeles Area in 2016.

It was incorporated on February 14, 1908. The city is in the South Bay region of the Greater Los Angeles Area. City of Champions Stadium is under construction in the city and when finished around 2019 will be the home of the Los Angeles Rams, which moved back to the Los Angeles Area in 2016.

enrich_metadata.label: Oakland, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco. Oakland's territory covers what was once a mosaic of coastal terrace prairie, oak woodland, and north coastal scrub. Its land served as a rich resource when its hillside oak and redwood timber were logged to build San Francisco, and Oakland's fertile flatland soils helped it become a prolific agricultural region. In the late 1860s, Oakland was selected as the western terminal of the Transcontinental Railroad. Following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, many San Franciscans relocated to Oakland, enlarging the city's population, increasing its housing stock and improving its infrastructure. It continued to grow in the 20th century with its busy port, shipyards, and a thriving automobile manufacturing industry. Oakland is known for its sustainability practices, including a top ranking for usage of electricity from renewable resources. Oakland is also known for its history of political activism, as well as its professional sports franchises and major corporations, which include health care, dot-com companies and manufacturers of household products. In addition, thanks to a steady influx of immigrants during the 20th century, along with thousands of African-American war-industry workers who relocated from the Deep South during the 1940s, Oakland is one of the most ethnically diverse major cities in the country.

enrich_metadata.label: Ukiah, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Ukiah, Mendocino County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Ukiah (/juːˈkaɪ.ə/ yew-KY-ə; formerly Ukiah City) is the county seat and largest city of Mendocino County, California. With its accessible location (along the U.S. Route 101 corridor several miles south of CA 20), Ukiah serves as the city center for Mendocino County and much of neighboring Lake County. The Ukiah Valley is a center of a major wine production industry. In 1996, Ukiah was ranked the #1 best small town to live in California and the sixth-best place to live in the United States. The population was 16,075 at the 2010 census.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Ukiah,_California

enrich_metadata.label: Merced, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Merced /mərˈsɛd/ (Spanish for "Mercy") is a city in, and the county seat of, Merced County in the San Joaquin Valley of Northern California. As of 2014, the city had a population of 81,743. Incorporated on April 1, 1889, Merced is a charter city that operates under a council-manager government. It is named after the Merced River, which flows nearby. Merced, known as the "Gateway to Yosemite," is less than two hours by automobile from Yosemite National Park to the east and Monterey Bay, the Pacific Ocean, and several beaches to the west. The community is served by the rail passenger service Amtrak, a major airline through Merced Regional Airport, and three bus lines. It is approximately 110 miles (180 km) from Sacramento, 130 miles (210 km) from San Francisco, 45 miles (72 km) from Fresno, and 270 miles (430 km) from Los Angeles. In 2005, the city became home to the tenth University of California campus, University of California, Merced (UC Merced), the first research university built in the U.S. in the 21st century.

enrich_metadata.label: Berkeley, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Berkeley, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Berkeley (/ˈbɜːrkliː/ BURK-lee) is a city on the east shore of San Francisco Bay in northern Alameda County, California. It is named after the 18th-century Anglo-Irish bishop and philosopher George Berkeley. It borders the cities of Oakland and Emeryville to the south and the city of Albany and unincorporated community of Kensington to the north. Its eastern border with Contra Costa County generally follows the ridge of the Berkeley Hills. Its population at the 2010 census was 112,580. Berkeley is the site of the oldest campus in the University of California system – the University of California, Berkeley – of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory which is managed and operated by the university, and the Graduate Theological Union. It is one of the most politically liberal cities in the United States.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Berkeley,_California

enrich_metadata.label: Richmond, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Richmond (/ˈrɪtʃmənd/ RICH-mənd) is a city in western Contra Costa County, California, United States. The city was incorporated on August 7, 1905. Located in the eastern region of the San Francisco Bay Area, Richmond borders the cities of San Pablo, Albany, El Cerrito and Pinole in addition to the unincorporated communities of North Richmond, Hasford Heights, Kensington, El Sobrante, Bayview-Montalvin Manor, Tara Hills, and East Richmond Heights, and briefly San Francisco on Red Rock Island. Under the McLaughlin Administration, Richmond was the largest city in the United States served by a Green Party mayor. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the city's population is at 103,710, making it the second largest city in the United States to be named Richmond, after Richmond, Virginia.

enrich_metadata.label: Needles, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Needles, San Bernardino County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Needles (Mojave: ʼAha Kuloh) is a city in San Bernardino County, California, United States. It lies on the western banks of the Colorado River in the Mohave Valley subregion of the Mojave Desert, near the borders of Arizona and Nevada and roughly 110 miles (180 km) from the Las Vegas Strip. It is also the easternmost city of the Greater Los Angeles area. The city is accessible via Interstate 40 and U.S. Route 95. The population was 4,844 at the 2010 census, up from 4,830 at the 2000 census. Needles was named after "The Needles", a group of pinnacles, mountain peaks in the Mohave Mountains on the Arizona side of the river to the south of the city. The large Mohave Native American community shares the nearby Fort Mojave Indian Reservation and the town. Needles is a gateway to the Mojave National Preserve.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Needles,_California

enrich_metadata.label: Beverly Hills, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Beverly Hills is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States, surrounded by the cities of Los Angeles and West Hollywood. Originally a Spanish ranch where lima beans were grown, Beverly Hills was incorporated in 1914 by a group of investors who had failed to find oil, but found water instead and eventually decided to develop it into a town. By 2013, its population had grown to 34,658. Sometimes referred to as "90210", one of its primary ZIP codes, it is home to many actors and celebrities. The city includes the Rodeo Drive shopping district and the Beverly Hills Oil Field.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Beverly_Hills,_California

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Rafael (/ˌsæn rəˈfɛl/ SAN rə-FEL; [san rafaˈel]) (Spanish for "Saint Raphael") is a city and the county seat of Marin County, California, United States. The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Carlos is a city in San Mateo County, California, USA on the San Francisco Peninsula, about halfway between San Francisco and San Jose. It is a small affluent residential suburb located between Belmont to the north and Redwood City to the south. The population was 28,406 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.comment: San Carlos is a city in San Mateo County, California, USA on the San Francisco Peninsula, about halfway between San Francisco and San Jose. It is a small affluent residential suburb located between Belmont to the north and Redwood City to the south. The population was 28,406 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.label: San Diego
enrich_metadata.mention_address: San Diego, San Diego County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Diego /ˌsæn diːˈeɪɡoʊ/ (Spanish for "Saint Didacus") is a major city in California, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Southern California, approximately 120 miles (190 km) south of Los Angeles and immediately adjacent to the border with Mexico. With an estimated population of 1,381,069 as of July 1, 2014, San Diego is the eighth-largest city in the United States and second-largest in California. San Diego is the birthplace of California and is known for its mild year-round climate, natural deep-water harbor, extensive beaches, long association with the U.S. Navy, and recent emergence as a healthcare and biotechnology development center. Historically home to the Kumeyaay people, San Diego was the first site visited by Europeans on what is now the West Coast of the United States. Upon landing in San Diego Bay in 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claimed the entire area for Spain, forming the basis for the settlement of Alta California 200 years later. The Presidio and Mission of San Diego, founded in 1769, formed the first European settlement in what is now California. In 1821, San Diego became part of newly independent Mexico, and in 1850, became part of the United States following the Mexican–American War and the admission of California to the union. The city is the seat of San Diego County and is the economic center of the region as well as the San Diego–Tijuana metropolitan area. San Diego's main economic engines are military and defense-related activities, tourism, international trade, and manufacturing. The presence of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), with the affiliated UCSD Medical Center, has helped make the area a center of research in biotechnology.

san diego.address: San Diego, San Diego County, California, United States of America

attraction_reviewComments: First time here. Until recently, I have never had friends buried here. Respect for our fallen veterans is displayed well here. When in Riverside, take some time to visit our... read more
Went to pay respects, and while there learned about the Medal Of Honor Memorial. It is worth the time to visit, and is well maintained.
Came here in April 2013 to visit my father's gravesite. He was a WWII vet, who moved from Midwest to LA in 1980s. Can't express how lovely the grounds are, and how meaningful it... read more
Great place to honor our countries heroes. Very quiet and a place of great respect, easy access from the freeway.
My parents are both buried here. My father served time in the Navy and our family was very proud of his service and being able to be Interred in this Military Cemetery. The... read more
I took a nice drive around the grounds on this gloomy rainy day. The cemetery is very well maintained and a respectful place for our honored veterens. The ponds, fountains and... read more
This park is close to our home. We frequently wander about this beautiful place. It is kept immaculate. It has one of four Metal of Honor Memorials in the United States. But, it... read more
A friend and co-worker from my first overseas assignment is buried here. Unlike other VA cemeteries the grave markers are all flush with the ground. It's a very nice, peaceful... read more
This place is beautiful and the service locations are all wonderful with some having stunning views. The locations for interment and inurment are wonderful.
I've visited this place every year for the past 12 years and it just keeps getting better and better. The grounds are well manicured and well maintained. Over time the desert... read more
Well organized, very somber and honoring. Clean restrooms (always a plus). Great staff. Well groomed grounds but being revamped. That was fine. Did not like the fact that... read more
This is by far, the most beautiful cemetery in all of California. Many war veterans and some of their spouses are buried here. On Memorial Day, all the markers have a USA flag... read more

enrich_metadata.label: Civic Center, Bakersfield
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Bakersfield, Kern County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Civic Center is a district in Downtown Bakersfield, California. It is the center of government for the City of Bakersfield and the County of Kern, containing a collection of buildings used by the city, county, state, and federal governments. The district also contains all of downtown's sporting complexes. It also has the Rabobank Theater and Convention Center, which is the largest theater and convention facilities in the city.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Civic_Center,_Bakersfield
enrich_metadata.comment: Civic Center is a district in Downtown Bakersfield, California. A few nifty boutiques and food places littered along this street. I would drive until I see something I like before stopping by. Quite a distance to walk

We really enjoyed walking here and stopping to eat and drink in plenty of different places. Will be back.
Great street to go for an explore along. Plenty of places to stop and have a bite to eat. Worth a wander :)

We walked the length of this road and it was a great thing to do, stopped off at random places and see how the rich and famous live their lives.
Walked a long way on the Sunset Boulevard to see the Sunset Strip. The street in itself had a lot of places to see along the way. It was nice.

This was a really fun and vibrant place to visit. There was a substantial amount if entertainment and several good restaurants to eat at while you are there.

You can see some great music here, find different restaurants, or get ripped off. At night you can see some really different types of fauna.

enrich_metadata.label: Dana Point, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Dana Point, Orange County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing. The city was named after the headland of Dana Point, which was in turn named after Richard Henry Dana, Jr., author of Two Years Before the Mast, which included a description of the area. Dana described the locale, including neighboring San Juan Capistrano, as "the only romantic spot on the coast". Although Dana described the anchorage as poor, it is now a developed harbor and contains a replica of his ship, the Pilgrim. The Pilgrim is used as a classroom by the Ocean Institute, which is located at the harbor. This area is designated California Historical Landmark #189.

enrich_metadata.label: Arcata, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Arcata, California Arcata (Hupa: do'-khah-oon-tetl ding', meaning "big flat place") originally Union Town or Union, is a city adjacent to the Arcata Bay (northern) portion of Humboldt Bay in Humboldt County, California, United States. At the 2010 census, Arcata's population was 17,231. Arcata, located 280 miles (450 km) north of San Francisco (via Highway 101), is home to Humboldt State University. Arcata is also the location of the Arcata Field Office of the Federal Bureau of Land Management, which is responsible for the administration of natural resources, lands, and mineral programs, including the Headwaters Forest, on approximately 200,000 acres of public land in Northwestern California.

At the 2010 census, Arcata's population was 17,231. Arcata, located 280 miles (450 km) north of San Francisco (via Highway 101), is home to Humboldt State University. Arcata is also the location of the Arcata Field Office of the Federal Bureau of Land Management, which is responsible for the administration of natural resources, lands, and mineral programs, including the Headwaters Forest, on approximately 200,000 acres of public land in Northwestern California.

enrich_metadata.label: Burbank, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Burbank, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Burbank is a city in Los Angeles County in Southern California, United States, 12 miles (19 km) northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The population at the 2010 census was 103,340. Billed as the "Media Capital of the World" and only a few miles northeast of Hollywood, numerous media and entertainment companies are headquartered or have significant production facilities in Burbank, including The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Entertainment, ABC Studios, ABC Family, Marvel Studios, Nickelodeon, NBC, and Insomniac Games. The city is also home to Bob Hope Airport. Burbank also holds a special place in aerospace history since Lockheed's Skunk Works in Burbank produced some of the most secret and technologically advanced airplanes, including the U-2 spy planes that uncovered the Soviet Union missile components in Cuba. Burbank consists of two distinct areas: a downtown, in the foothills of the Verdugo Mountains, and flatlands, at the east end of the San Fernando Valley. At one time, it was referred to as "Beautiful Downtown Burbank" on Laugh-In and The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson. The city was named after David Burbank, a New Hampshire-born dentist and entrepreneur.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burbank,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Burbank is a city in Los Angeles County in Southern California, United States, 12 miles (19 km) northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The population at the 2010 census was 103,340.Billed as the "Media Capital of the World" and only a few miles northeast of Hollywood, numerous media and entertainment companies are headquartered or have significant production facilities in Burbank, including The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Entertainment, ABC Studios, ABC Family, Marvel Studios, Nickelodeon, NBC, and Insomniac Games. The city is also home to Bob Hope Airport. Burbank also holds a special place in aerospace history since Lockheed's Skunk Works in Burbank produced some of the most secret and technologically advanced airplanes, including the U-2 spy planes that uncovered the Soviet Union miss

attraction_reviewComments: Walking down the main street and found Bubblegum Alley, between 2 stores. It is gross, but worth a peek, for a few minutes.
This alley is so cool. It is gross but entirely fascinating. It's something to see but it's just a five minute experience.
It was just by chance that we happened upon this bubblegum alley. My daughter was not real impressed. I had a good laugh. I liked to see how artistic people can be with... read more
While out walking around it is a fun spot to check out. I can at least take comfort in the fact it wasn't all one person doing the chewing.
I love seeing people reactions to the photos of this place, we heard about it and as we were in the area thought we'd hunt it down. It was really rather disgusting, but funny to... read more
It's a little gross sice there are literally thousands (mor like hindreds of thousands) of people's gum on the wall...not sanitary! But, I like it because it is interesting and I... read more
We stopped by this little curiosity while exploring downtown. The legend is more impressive than the actual site, which is really just a bunch of gum and wrappers stuck to a... read more
Started out years ago with students getting rid of chewing gum and it has grown to what it is today; a novelty place known all over the world. Go see it for yourself.
The history is fascinating. Ou could do a photo stop here after the CA 1 drive. San luis obiespo is a beautiful town and you could walk around the downtown where the alley is... read more
For some odd reason, bubblegum alley gets a lot of attention and is one the "attractions" to see. We came across it by accident and I have to say it was quite disgusting and had... read more
It's like no other alley you have seen before. It's local tradition to stick your chewed up gum on the alley wall. It's gross and stinky, but it is definitely a must see when u... read more
Dark, smelly alley with chewing gum covering the walls. Unbelievable. This ranks right up there with the Springfield Tire Fire. It's really cool to be able to say you've seen... read more
The alley is literally full of chewed gum which is gross but I'm glad that we stopped to see it, it was kind of fun to add to it too
Fun, silly thing to see when you visit SLO. They say it started as a senior class, high school thing --- some say it was par at of a rivalry between the local high school and... read more
It was kinda gross but pretty neat at the same time to see messages and see all the different places people came from to see the ally
It's something you have to see and it will make you laugh to be standing in an alley where the walls are covered in bubblegum! If you start thinking about all the germs and etc... read more
All the hype I had to check it out. It is really gross but in a fun interesting way. My daughters had the best time and were able to stick their gum on the wall. Will be fun to... read more
Visited the bubblegum alley in San luis obispo and it definitely a must see while here. It's gross but very interesting. Day time visits are better for photos as even though the... read more
Only takes 5 minutes to visit. If you are in the area, this is a great photo spot. I wouldn't travel far out of my way to go here, but if you are walking around town, this is a... read more
I had seen this alley when visiting with my dad two years earlier so I had to show my wife, who chews bubblegum, this landmark. Added our spent gum and left our mark. Smells... read more
This was a very interesting site, loaded with gum wads but kind of gross at the same time. But it is something to see so you can say you saw it or even add to it if you choose
You need a strong stomach and good sense of humor to make good by this experience...Still, like rubber necking on a freeway, it is hard to resist.
We were just walking down the street when I turned to look down the ally and saw this. You know you must be in a college town when you see this. I just had to laugh, take a couple... read more
It is interesting to say the least, but kind of gross especially if you are a germaphope. I think everyone should take a look because of the interesting factor. That is a lot... read more
Visiting from England, we don't have anything like this so we thought we'd check it out. It is what it is I guess there's only so much you can write about an alley full of gum! I... read more
It is a very unusual sight but the whole alley is covered in over 2million pieces if chewed chewing gum. You are welcome to add to it but for me it just looked tacky & dirty 😩
It's nasty but somewhat interesting. My step-father was telling me about it and I didn't quit understand what it was until I showed up. I guess if you like that sort of thing go... read more
I call it hepatitis alley. DO NOT TOUCH THE WALLS. Just look at it, take a picture, check in, and move along lol.
Singapore's nightmare! Pretty unusual, it's basically an alleyway on the Main Street that you'll likely pass anyway so why not have a look. It is what it says on the tin.
We just happened upon Bubblegum Alley while going back to the parking lot where we had left our car. I haven't decided if I was grossed out or fascinated. I guess it was a... read more
I saw this when visiting my sister who lives in San Luis Obispo. It is located between two business in central downtown area of the city. It is a rather small alley that is a... read more
I always take our guest to SLO here. Some people love it and others are disgusted by it. It's a small alley that has been completely covered by people's chewing gum over the... read more
What a hoot! The secret stories chewed into each piece of gum would fill a diary worth reading. Very unique.
Not much to see, but all the gum stuck on the wall. Be sure to bring your own piece of gum to mark your place in history at Bubblegum Alley! (I forgot mine!)
When I first heard of this place I definitely thought it would be interesting and did a detour. As the name suggests its a very small narrow passageway in the middle of the... read more
The kids seems to enjoy seeing this. Lots of old gum holding the history of slo. The inside of the wall belongs to blast 825 tap room that is opening next week.
This was a stop on our road trip up the California coast. Interesting that this has become a place to see. A bunch of people's used gum!! If you are in the city, could make it... read more
Kids liked it. Have Doc Bernstein ice cream on the same street as bubblegum alley. Amazing ice cream flavors!
It's tempting to gross your friends out by getting really close to some gum, stuck up on the wall from who knows when. But, from my experience, don't pretend to take a bite out... read more
It's a wall of gum!!! Just don't fall against it, yuk! You can add to it! Chew your gum before you get there. Interesting to look at while waiting for the Thursday evening... read more
Our 10 year old boy thought this was a hoot and proudly added his contribution. Since it's so centrally located, it's an easy stop. The smell of 1,000 different flavors of gum... read more
We were visiting SLO to attend the Higuera Street Fair/Farmers Market. We passed by Bubble Gum Alley. Interesting but gross!! Lol
While walking downtown San Luis Obispo my friend and I came across Bubblegum Alley. We had heard of it but weren't seeking it out. But there it was. There were lots of people... read more
Wow! So much chewed bubble gum I've never seen in my life! So much color and bizarre shapes... amazing! But don't get overexcited there as you might get disgust from thinking how... read more
Lets think about this... thousands of pieces of Bubblegum stuck on the walls of a very narrow alley. A one time visit takes care of this one. I felt like the germs were reaching... read more
Not a whole lot to say about this. It's just a little walkway between stores downtown. If you blink you'll miss it. Take hand sanitizer if you're going to "contribute" to the art... read more
When my kids were little, they loved a visit to Bubblegum Alley. Now that they are in their 20's, I might take them by there next time we are all together in the area!
But unique, can't say more really But trip advisor wants 100 characters If passing it's worth a pose but nothing more 😹👍🏻
If you are in SLO - you might as well visit. Smells of gum. Don't lean on the wall. Nothing else to say really, It's a wall covered in chewing gum.
It is an interesting and a MUST STOP if you are NEARBY. It is a short alley where both walls are filled with bubble gums. The alley is near restaurants and shops in SLO (just... read more
Not quite as impressive as the Seattle gum wall, but the closeness of the walls does make this gum wall a lot more homey!
This was one of the many stops we made on our 3 week tour of California in June Been there done that. You can smell the sweet perfumed air before you get to the alley. Some... read more
